lines.text: The time to make up your mind about people is never.
What is thee wish?
I'm looking for some local b - what'd you say?
What is thee wish?
Um, local biography or history.
If thee will consult with my colleague in there.
Mm-hm. Dost thou have a washroom?
[the librarian points]
Thank thee.
You'll never be a first class human being or a first class woman until you've learned to have some regard for human frailty.
The course of true love...
...gathers no moss.
Tracy.
What do you want?
You're wonderful. There's a magnificence in you, Tracy.
Now I'm getting self-conscious. It's funny. I - Mike? Let's...
Yeah?
I don't know - go up, I guess, it's late.

A magnificence that comes out of your eyes, in your voice, in the way you stand there, in the way you walk. You're lit from within, Tracy. You've got fires banked down in you, hearth-fires and holocausts.
I don't seem to you made of bronze?
No, you're made out of flesh and blood. That's the blank, unholy surprise of it. You're the golden girl, Tracy. Full of life and warmth and delight. What goes on? You've got tears in your eyes.
Shut up, shut up. Oh, Mike. Keep talking, keep talking. Talk, will you?
But a man expects his wife to...
Behave herself. Naturally.
To behave herself naturally.
[George gives him a look]
Sorry.
You've got all the arrogance of your class, haven't you?
What have classes to do with it? What do they matter except for the people in them? George comes from the so-called lower class, Dexter, the upper. Well?
Well...
Mac the night watchman is a prince among men, Uncle Willie is a... pincher. Upper and lower my eye. I'll take the lower, thanks.
If you can't get a drawing room.
What does that mean?
My mistake.
Decidedly. You're insulting!
Sorry.
Oh, don't apologize!
Well, who's apologizing?
I never knew such a man.
You wouldn't be likely to, from where you sit!
Talk about arrogance.
Tracy.
What do you want?

[pause]
You're wonderful.
Doggone it, C.K. Dexter Haven. Either I'm gonna sock you or you're gonna sock me.
Shall we toss a coin?
Where's my wandering parakeet?
[Dexter has just proposed]
Oh Dexter you're not doing it just to soften the blow?
No.
Nor to save my face?
Oh, it's a nice little face.
Oh Dexter, I'll be yar now, I promise to be yar.
Be whatever you like, you're my redhead.
I'm testing the air. I like it but it doesn't like me.
I would sell my grandmother for a drink - and you know how I love my grandmother.
What's this room? I've forgotten my compass.
I'd say, south-by-southwest parlor-by-living-room.
This is the Bridal Suite. Would you send up a couple of caviar sandwiches and a bottle of beer?
What? Who is this?
This is the Voice of Doom calling. Your days are numbered, to the seventh son of the seventh son.
Hello? Hello?
What's the matter?
One of the servants has been at the sherry again.

[Tracy and Mike have almost kissed. Both are very drunk]
Has your mind taken hold again, dear professor?
Good thing, don't you agree?
No, professor.

[angrily]
Alright, lay off that "professor" stuff! Now, do you hear me?
Yes, professor...

[hung over]
Awww... this is one of those days that the pages of history teach us are best spent lying in bed.
Oh it's all right Tracy. We all go haywire at times and if we don't, maybe we ought to.
Sometimes, for your own sake, Red, I think you should've stuck to me longer.
I thought it was for life, but the nice judge gave me a full pardon.
Aaah, that's the old redhead. No bitterness, no recrimination, just a good swift left to the jaw.
Dexter, say something.
Well, I...
Oh, Dexter, I'm such an unholy mess of a girl.
Well, that's no good. That's not even conversation.
You're like some marvelous, distant, well, queen, I guess. You're so cool and fine and always so much your own. There's a kind of beautiful purity about you, Tracy, like, like a statue.
George...
Oh, it's grand, Tracy. It's what everybody feels about you. It's what I first worshipped you for from afar.
I don't want to be worshipped. I want to be loved.
You're too good for me, George. You're a hundred times too good. And I'd make you most unhappy, most. That is, I'd do my best to.
Oh, dear. Is there no such thing as privacy any more?
Only in bed, mother, and not always there.

[drunk]
You going my way miss?

[drunk]
That's "Miss Goddess" to you
Okay, Miss Goddess To Me.
I'm sorry, but I thought I better hit you before he did. He's in better shape than I am.
Well you'll do!

[a very drunk Tracy]
My feet are made of clay. Made of clay, did you know? Good niiiggghhhttt little man!
My, she was yar...
My father was a history teacher.
English history has always fascinated me. Robin Hood, Cromwell, Jack the Ripper. Where did he teach? Your father I mean.
What most wives fail to realize is that their husband's philandering has nothing whatever to do with them.
Oh? Then what has it to do with?
A reluctance to go grow old, I think.
There's a cousin, Joanna, who's definitely crazy.
Who told you that.
Dinah.
Well Dinah would know.
Oh Tracy darling...
Mike...
What can I say to you? Tell me darling.
Not anything - don't say anything. And especially not "darling."

[walks in on Tracy and Dexter together]
Well, I suppose I should object to this twosome.
That would be most objectionable.

[looking for the "hair of the dog"]
Do you s'pose, sir, speaking of eye-openers...?
Oh, that's the first sane remark I've heard today. C'malong, Dexter, I know a formula that's said to pop the pennies off the eyelids of dead Irishmen.
Put me in your pocket, Mike.
You hardly know him.
To hardly know him is to know him well.
Of course, Mr. Connor, she's a girl who is generous to a fault.
To a fault.
Except to other people's faults.
Orange juice, certainly.
Don't tell me you've forsaken your beloved whisky and whiskies.
No-no-no-no. I've just changed their colour, that's all. I'm going for the pale pastel shades now. They're more becoming of me. How about you, Mr. Connor? You drink, don't you - alcohol, I mean?
Oh, a little.

[Amused]
A little? And you a writer? Tsk, tsk, tsk. I thought all writers drank to excess and beat their wives. You know, at one time I think I secretly wanted to be a writer.
[He and Tracy exchange scornful looks]
We both might face the facts that neither of us has proved to be a very great success as a wife.
We just picked the wrong first husband.
an understanding heart. And without that you might just as well be made of bronze.
Oh, we're going to talk about me again, are we? Goody.
Champagne's funny stuff. I'm used to whiskey. Whiskey is a slap on the back, and champagne's heavy mist before my eyes.
You haven't switched from liquor to dope, by any chance, have you Dexter?
You seem quite contemptuous of me all of the sudden.
No Red, not of you, never of you.
These stories are beautiful. Why, Mike, they're almost poetry.
Don't kid yourself, they are.
Nothing ever possibly in the least ever happens here. Mother, how do you get smallpox?

[speaking of Tracy]
What are her leading characteristics?
She has a horror of men who wear their hats in the house.
Leading characteristics to be filled in later.
the rich, rapacious, American female. There's no other country where she exists.
And would I change places with Tracy Samantha Lord for all her wealth and beauty? Oh boy just ask me.

[drunk, to driver]
Well, this is where Cinderella gets off, now you hurry back to the ball before you turn into a pumpkin and six white mice, goodbye.
Aren't you coming Liz?
Well, it seems I've got to commit suicide first.
You're just a mass of prejudices, aren't you? You're so much thought and so little feeling, Professor.
Hello friends and enemies.
Young man, remove yourself!
How are you, sir?
I don't know. Get along! Get along!
I'm going to build you an ivory tower with my own two hands.
Like fun you are.
Must we ride in this thing? Wouldn't we be more comfortable on pogo sticks?
You really hate me, don't you Connor?
Oh no!
[pause]
I don't like you very much though.

[normal voice]
Hello, Dexter.
[lower voice]
Hello, George.
[high childish voice]
Hello, Mike.

[leering at Liz]
Ah Ms. Embry, you're a vision of lovliness. May I offer you a cocktail? Or champagne?
Oh champagne, I've never had enough.
You will... tonight.

[watching Kittredge clumsily mount a horse]
Heigh Ho Silver.

[Dexter has butted in]
You keep out of this.
You forget I am out of it.

[on her wedding day]
Do you like my dress, Dinah?
Oh, yes. Ever so much.
Feels awfully heavy.
A wedding day inside mainline society.
Or what the kitchen maid saw through the keyhole. Unquote.

[calling outside his house]
C.K. Dexter Haven! Oh, C.K. Dexter Haven!

[coming to the door in his pajamas]
What's up?
You are.
I only hope it's worth it. Come in.
[hung over, moans as the pony cart Dinah's driving hits a bump]
What's wrong?
Oh, nothing, nothing. My head just fell off, that's all.
I'm going crazy. I'm standing here solidly on my own two hands and going crazy.
It can't be anything like love, can it?
No, no, it can't be.
Would it be inconvenient?
Terribly.
I never knew such a man.
You're not likely to dear. Not from where you sit.
I thought all writers drank to excess and beat their wives. You know one time I secretly wanted to be a writer.
Tell four footmen to call me in time for lunch will you?
No hunter of buckshot in the rear is cagey, crafty Connor. Un-quote. Close paragraph.
Close job. Close bank account.
The moon is also a goddess, chaste and virginal.
Stop using those foul words.
[Liz screams as Uncle Willie pinches her on the rear]
Don't DO that!
I... I feel exactly as though I'd been pinched.
Don't you think you weren't.
Are you one of the musicians?
No!
Oh of course, you're Junius's friend. Only you're not. Do you have any violin strings?

[digs in his pocket]
I have an aspirin. Will that work?
I don't think so! It's for a violin. Oh well, no matter!
Oh, it won't rain. Tracy won't stand for it.

[to the butler]
The Queen will have bread and honey at the usual time.
[Mike discovers the intercom in the Lords' house]
Uh-oh, Liz, what did I tell you? Look, how do you like this - living room, sitting room, terrace, pool, stables.
That's probably so they can talk to the horses without having them in the house.
We've come for the body of Macaulay Connor.
I'm so glad you came. Can you use a typewriter?
No, thanks, I've got one at home.
Only for the moment, I'm not interested in myself.
Not interested in yourself, Red, you're fascinated. You're far and away your favorite person in the world.
Dexter, would you mind doing something for me?
Anything. What?
Get the heck out of here.
You hate me, I trust, Miss Imbrie.
No, I-I can't afford to hate anybody. I'm only a photographer.
Look, who's doing the interviewing here?
Do you think she caught on somehow?
No, she was born like that, don't let her throw you.
Do you want to take over?
I want to go home!
What's this? Is it my book?
Yes.
C. K. Dexter Haven you have unsuspected depth!
Thanks, old chap.
But have you read it?
When I was trying to stop drinking, I read anything.
And did you stop drinking?
Yes. Your book didn't do it though.

[taking the perfume out of the car]
This is your Uncle Willy's favorite, Complete Surrender.
I can't make you out at all now.
I thought I was easy.
So did I. But you're not. You talk so big and tough and then you write like this. Which is which?
Both. I guess.
No. No, I believe you put the toughness down to save your skin.
You think so?
Yes. I know a little about that.
You do?
Quite a lot.
C.K. Dexter Haven, I would like to talk to you.
Well, let's go in the talking room.

[referring to Dinah]
What's this?
Idiot, probably.

[drunk]
I bring you greetings and Cinderella's slipper, champagne. Champagne is a great leveleler... leveleler. It makes you my equal.
Not quite.
Well, almost my equal.

[to horse]
What's the matter, Bessie? You seem worried.
Maybe that's because his name is Jack.

[after Tracy has declined his last-minute marriage proposal]
But they're in there! They're waiting!
Don't get too conventional all at once, will you? There'll be a reaction.
I think that dress hikes up a little behind...
No, it's me that does.
I remember your honeymoon quite well. You and she on a little sail boat, the "True Love", wasn't it?
Yes it was. How did you know?
I was the only photographer whose camera you didn't smash. You were terribly nice about it. You threw it in the ocean.
Oh, one of those.
Yes I had the strange notion that our honeymoon was our own.
C.K. Dexter Haven, what kind of a name is that?
Macaulay Connor is no homespun tag, my pet.
Yeah, well you just try calling him Macaulay.
South Bend, it sounds almost like dancing.
How do I look?
Like a queen. Like a goddess.
And do you know how I feel?
How?
Like a human. Like a human being.

[after learning that Dexter is Tracy's ex-husband and is going to help with introducing him and Liz]
Holy mackerel. What goes on here?
The prettiest sight in this fine pretty world is the privileged class enjoying its privileges.
Hello you.
Hello.
You look fine.
I feel fine.
English history has always facinated me. Cromwell, Robin Hood, Jack the Ripper. Where did he teach? You're father, I mean.
I understand we understand each other.
I never thought that alcohol would - Oh shut up.
I don't think you're being fair to me, Mr. Kidd.
No?
No. You're treating me like you treat all your other writers.

[describing her "dream" to Tracy]
Do you know what I saw coming out of the woods?
I haven't the faintest idea, a skunk?
Can you use a typewriter?
No, thanks. I have one at home.
C.K. Dexter Haven! What a name tag!
Macauly Connor is no homespun tag either, my pet.
Yeah, well you just try calling him Macauly!
I knew a plain Joe Smith once. Worst rat I ever met.

[Turns towards Liz]
Maid of honour?
Matron.
[Looks at Liz, puzzled]
Joe Smith, hardware department.
